Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Inductively Coupled Plasma- Mass Spectrometry (ICP MS) for elemental concentration and speciation analysis at Montclair State University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will permit the acquisition of an Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometer (ICP-MS) to enhance research activities, hands-on education, and analytical training. Acquisition of a modern ICP-MS with superior analytical capabilities will enhance the research resources for the rapidly increasing student population at Montclair State University (undergraduate population >60% women and >20% minorities).

The ICP-MS will be shared by interdisciplinary research programs in the College of Science and Mathematics, College of Education and Human Services (CEHS), and the College of Humanities and Social Sciences (CHSS). The faculty of the College of Science and Mathematics actively involve undergraduate and graduate students in their field-based and laboratory-based research programs, which take place across the United Sates, South American, Europe, Asia, and Antarctica. Projects that will benefit from this instrument include contaminant identification and environmental remediation, petrology and volcanology studies, climate studies based on soil and sediment chemistry, water quality studies, food quality and food security studies, and archeological investigations that track building materials through their elemental fingerprints.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This MRI grant is one of several equipment grants that Montclair State University (MSU) has received in the last decade from NSF. The ICP MS acquired through this grant and new lines research among PI and Co-PIs has provided the impetus for MSU to build modern research laboratories. The ICP MS was shared by several interdisciplinary research programs in the College of Science and Mathematics (CSAM) at MSU. Earth and Environmental Studies (EAES) faculty and students are the heaviest users of the ICP-MS. The instrument has also generated data for projects conducted in the Departments of Chemistry and Biochemistry, CSAM.  In addition, the ICP-MS has been used by visiting students and faculty from regional institutions such as Rutgers-Newark and William Patterson University.

 

Instrument is being used heavily by faculty, postdoctoral associates, graduate and undergraduate students and technical staff in their research. In the past 5 years, this ICP-MS has supported 10 PhD students, 12 MS students and 9 undergraduates in MSU for their dissertation/thesis research. Twenty two journal papers and numerous conference presentations have been published using the data generated by this instrument. The ICP-MS is also used in Petrology class and in our instrumental Environmental Analysis course. It will continue to provide critical educational and instrument training opportunities for users with varying levels of expertise across a range of scientific disciplines.

 

Without the new ICP MS, a variety of research will not be possible at MSU. Just to highlight a few: 1) Sediment provenance signatures in Antarctic terrestrial and glacial marine sediment; 2) Heavy metal accumulation in the turtle tissue; 3) Heavy metal concentrations in soil samples from a contaminated brownfield; 4) Evaluate different treatment methods to remove heavy metals and phosphours in storm water and municipal wastewater samples; 5) Collect pilot data for a new project addressing the development of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet.

 

Acquisition of a modern ICP-MS with superior analytical capabilities has enhanced the research resources for the rapidly increasing student population at Montclair State University. The research conducted using ICP MS and the associated student mentoring was a large part of MSU recent designation as a Carnegie Doctoral Research University (one of the only 3 in New Jersey). These designations have made us eligible for new grant competition in basic and applied research and student training grant programs.

 

The faculties of CSAM actively involve undergraduate and graduate students in their field-based and laboratory-based research programs, which takes place across the United Sates, South American, Europe, Asia, and Antarctica. EAES houses approximately 200 students in bachelors, masters, and doctoral degree programs in geography, geoscience, sustainability science, environmental studies, and environmental management. Our students have gathered numerous data using the instrument and presented their research at regional and national meeting, such as Geological Society of America, the American Geophysical Union, and Association of Environmental Engineering & Science Professors. In addition to faculty and student thesis research, the instrument has been used for demonstrations for Open House recruiting events sponsored by the College of Science and Mathematics (https://www.montclair.edu/calendar/view-event.php?id=44046) and for the high school summer intern programs.
